quizName: NCLEX Quiz - Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an enteral route of medication administration?
options: Intravenous (IV) infusion
Subcutaneous injection
Intramuscular injection
Oral tablet
questions.explanation: The enteral route of medication administration involves administering medications orally, such as through tablets, capsules, or liquids that are swallowed and absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of using an intravenous (IV) infusion pump?
options: Prevent infection at the IV site
Control the rate of medication administration
Monitor vital signs during infusion
Ensure patient comfort during infusion
questions.answer: Control the rate of medication administration
questions.explanation: An intravenous (IV) infusion pump is used to control and regulate the rate of medication administration, ensuring accurate and controlled delivery of medications or fluids into the patient's bloodstream.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention when administering subcutaneous injections?
options: Inject the medication at a 90-degree angle
Pinch the skin before injection
Massage the injection site after administration
Use a large-gauge needle for faster absorption
questions.explanation: When administering subcutaneous injections, it is appropriate to pinch the skin at the injection site to create a skin fold, which helps ensure that the medication is injected into the subcutaneous tissue and not into muscle.

questions.question: True or False: Intramuscular (IM) injections are commonly administered into the adipose tissue.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: Intramuscular (IM) injections are administered directly into muscle tissue rather than adipose tissue. This route allows for faster absorption and distribution of medications.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention to prevent medication errors during administration?
options: Double-check the medication label with another nurse
Administer medications without interruption
Avoid documenting medication administration
Store medications in an unsecured location
questions.answer: Double-check the medication label with another nurse
questions.explanation:
Double-checking the medication label with another nurse is an appropriate nursing intervention to prevent medication errors. It helps ensure that the right medication is being administered to the right patient

 in the right dose and route.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a topical medication?
options: Oral capsule
Intravenous (IV) infusion
Eye drops
Intramuscular injection
questions.explanation: Topical medications are applied to the skin or mucous membranes and include ointments, creams, lotions, and eye drops. They are intended for local effects on the area of application.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention to ensure medication safety when administering intravenous (IV) medications?
options: Administer IV medications quickly to save time
Use the same IV line for multiple medications
Monitor the patient for any adverse reactions
Avoid verifying the medication label with another nurse
questions.answer: Monitor the patient for any adverse reactions
questions.explanation: Monitoring the patient for any adverse reactions is an important nursing intervention to ensure medication safety when administering intravenous (IV) medications. It allows for early detection and management of any potential complications.

questions.question: True or False: Intravenous (IV) medications bypass the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and are absorbed directly into the bloodstream.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: Intravenous (IV) medications are administered directly into the bloodstream, bypassing the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. This allows for rapid and complete absorption of the medication.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention when administering ear drops to a pediatric patient?
options: Administer the drops while the child is lying on the unaffected ear
Pull the pinna downward and backward to straighten the ear canal
Insert the dropper directly into the ear canal
Irrigate the ear canal after administering the drops
questions.answer: Pull the pinna downward and backward to straighten the ear canal
questions.explanation: When administering ear drops to a pediatric patient, it is appropriate to pull the pinna downward and backward to straighten the ear canal. This helps ensure accurate and proper instillation of the medication.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention when administering medications via a nasogastric tube?
options: Administer medications in a large bolus
Flush the tube with a small amount of water before and after medication administration
Use a small syringe for administration
Administer medications without checking for tube placement
questions.answer: Flush the tube with a small amount of water before and after medication administration
questions.explanation:
Fl

ushing the nasogastric tube with a small amount of water before and after medication administration helps ensure that the medication is fully delivered and prevents clogging of the tube. It also helps prevent medication residue from remaining in the tube.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention to promote patient safety during medication administration?
options: Administer medications without washing hands
Administer medications without explaining the purpose to the patient
Administer medications without reviewing the patient's allergies
Administer medications with proper identification of the patient
questions.answer: Administer medications with proper identification of the patient
questions.explanation: Administering medications with proper identification of the patient, such as using two patient identifiers, is an important nursing intervention to promote patient safety during medication administration. It helps prevent medication errors and ensures that the right medication is given to the right patient.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention when administering intramuscular (IM) injections?
options: Use a small-gauge needle for faster absorption
Aspirate for blood return before injection
Inject the medication rapidly
Apply pressure to the injection site after administration
questions.answer: Apply pressure to the injection site after administration
questions.explanation: Applying pressure to the injection site after administering an intramuscular (IM) injection helps reduce the risk of bleeding and promotes the absorption of the medication. It also helps minimize discomfort or pain at the injection site.

questions.question: True or False: Intradermal (ID) injections are commonly used for administering vaccines.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: Intradermal (ID) injections are commonly used for administering vaccines, such as the tuberculin skin test (PPD) and allergy testing. The injection is given just below the dermis layer of the skin.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention when administering medication via a metered-dose inhaler (MDI)?
options: Administer the medication during exhalation
Shake the MDI vigorously before use
Place the mouthpiece of the MDI between the teeth
Inhale rapidly and deeply after activating the MDI
questions.answer: Inhale rapidly and deeply after activating the MDI
questions.explanation: When administering medication via a metered-dose inhaler (MDI), it is important for the patient to inhale rapidly and deeply after activating the MDI. This helps ensure optimal delivery of the medication into the lungs.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention to prevent complications during intravenous (IV) therapy?
options: Change the IV site once a week
Keep the IV site uncovered
Use a small-gauge catheter for rapid infusion
Monitor the IV site for signs of infiltration or phlebitis
questions.answer: Monitor the IV site for signs of infiltration or phlebitis
questions.explanation: Monitoring the intravenous (IV) site for signs of infiltration or phlebitis is an appropriate nursing intervention to prevent complications during IV therapy. It allows for early detection and intervention to prevent further complications.
